text: [Music]
this is Joe dear adorn of the New York
Times reporting from Gaza City where we
saw the deadliest day of this escalated
conflict with a massive strike this
afternoon on the house in Gaza City
killing 12 people most of them belong to
a single family the father survived and
many many people from the neighborhood
watched for more than an hour as they
struggled to pull bodies many of them
children out of rubble the death toll
here is now over 60 there are also three
Israelis killed on Thursday in the town
of Kiryat Malathi rockets continued to
fly from Gaza into Israel with direct
hits today in Ashdod where 10 Rockets
flew and all but one were intercepted by
the Iron Dome missile defense system
also directed in Ashkelon and the
southern town of shtetl there were
missiles again headed towards Tel Aviv
but they too were intercepted
after several days and weeks of
increased rocket fire from Gaza into
Israel Israel responded forcefully on
Wednesday by killing ahmed al jobari he
was the operational commander of the
al-qassam brigades which is Hamas is
militant wing and that's what really set
this in motion in the last several days
of extreme violence punishing airstrikes
by Israel endless launches of rockets by
Hamas and other militant factions here
all this violence makes the
possibilities of a ceasefire seem very
remote to the people here but there are
talks going on in Cairo in Washington
and in Jerusalem towards a possible deal
Egypt is trying to broker such a deal
between Hamas and Israel with the help
of Turkey and Qatar the Palestinian
leadership in the West Bank is also
trying to get involved they plan to call
tonight on the Arab League to use its
leverage to try to broker a deal and one
of their representatives Nabil Shah is
scheduled to land tonight here in Gaza
to visit with people and work with laws
for years ago
Israel's ground operations split the
Gaza Strip into killed hundreds and
hundreds of people over two weeks and
terrorize the population
nobody wants a repeat of that not Israel
which lost a lot of legitimacy in the
international community and certainly
not the Palestinians but it's unclear if
there's any way to reach a deal to avoid
it
